title: Question 243

children: A 35-year-old man has right eye redness and thick, globular yellow discharge without ocular pain. The discharge rapidly accumulates after it is wiped away. He also reports that his eyelids stick together in the morning. He wears contact lenses.
Examination shows mucopurulent discharge at the lid margins and diffuse conjunctival injection of the right eye. Vision is normal.
He is instructed to stop wearing his contact lenses.
Which of the following is the most appropriate additional treatment?

Bacterial conjunctivitis is characterized by redness and thick purulent discharge in one or, less commonly, both eyes; in the morning, the eye is “glued shut,” and discharge is thick and globular and continues throughout the day.
Bacterial conjunctivitis in adults who do not use contact lenses is commonly caused by
Staphylococcus aureus
Streptococcus
species, or
Moraxella catarrhalis
and can be treated with erythromycin ointment or trimethoprim-polymyxin drops; in contact lens wearers,
Pseudomonas
is common in addition to these species, so the preferred treatment is topical fluoroquinolone therapy.
The most appropriate treatment is a topical fluoroquinolone, such as ciprofloxacin eyedrops (
Option B

), for this patient with probable bacterial conjunctivitis, a bacterial infection of the conjunctiva that causes redness and thick purulent discharge in one or, less commonly, both eyes. In the morning, the eye is “glued shut.” The discharge in bacterial conjunctivitis is thick and globular and continues throughout the day. This is unlike the discharge of viral or allergic conjunctivitis, which is typically watery during the day and does not quickly recur. Bacterial conjunctivitis in adults who do not use contact lenses is commonly caused by
Staphylococcus aureus
Streptococcus
species, or
Moraxella catarrhalis
and can be treated with erythromycin ointment or trimethoprim-polymyxin drops (
Option D
). In contact lens wearers,
Pseudomonas

is common in addition to these species, so the preferred treatment is topical fluoroquinolone therapy and discontinuation of contact lens use. Of note, patients with a red eye should be evaluated for warning signs and symptoms that would prompt urgent ophthalmology referral, including pain, reduction of visual acuity, photophobia, corneal opacity, or pupillary defects. This patient does not exhibit these symptoms.

Patients with allergic conjunctivitis often have ocular discharge that is typically watery, not persistently mucopurulent as seen in this patient. Allergic conjunctivitis usually presents with itching of the eyes, and patients also may report burning or grittiness. Systemic symptoms, such as sneezing or nasal congestion, are common. Topical antihistamine eyedrops, such as cetirizine eyedrops (
Option A
), are helpful for patients who have allergic conjunctivitis but are inadequate treatment for patients with contact lens−related bacterial conjunctivitis.
Glucocorticoid eye drops, such as prednisolone (
Option C

), have no value in the treatment of bacterial conjunctivitis and are associated with many harms, including worsening of infection, corneal scarring, and perforation. Longer-term consequences may include cataracts and glaucoma.

references: Lin A, Rhee MK, Akpek EK, et al; American Academy of Ophthalmology Preferred Practice Pattern Cornea and External Disease Panel. Bacterial keratitis Preferred Practice Pattern
